subject: Symlink all non Dockerfile resources in images
commit_message:
Symlink all non Dockerfile resources in images

The only files in the docker image directories that differ majorly between
distros are the Dockerfiles (e.g. different package manager mechanisms,
different repo sources, etc).

The supporting files such as the start.sh/check.sh and config files should
largely stay the same between base images.

This change moves these files up into a "common" directory, and symlinks them
in the same way that the build script is managed. This means when adding a new
base distro only new Dockerfiles need to be created. Also, if a distro does
happen to require a vastly different start.sh script for example, one can
choose to simply not symlink to the common and instead drop in a custom one.

subject: Use just IP, not port, when determining partition placement
commit_message:
Use just IP, not port, when determining partition placement

In the ring builder, we place partitions with maximum possible
dispersion across tiers, where a "tier" is region, then zone, then
IP/port,then device. Now, instead of IP/port, just use IP. The port
wasn't really getting us anything; two different object servers on two
different ports on one machine aren't separate failure
domains. However, if someone has only a few machines and is using one
object server on its own port per disk, then the ring builder would
end up with every disk in its own IP/port tier, resulting in bad (with
respect to durability) partition placement.

For example: assume 1 region, 1 zone, 4 machines, 48 total disks (12
per machine), and one object server (and hence one port) per
disk. With the old behavior, partition replicas will all go in the one
region, then the one zone, then pick one of 48 IP/port pairs, then
pick the one disk therein. This gives the same result as randomly
picking 3 disks (without replacement) to store data on; it completely
ignores machine boundaries.

With the new behavior, the replica placer will pick the one region,
then the one zone, then one of 4 IPs, then one of 12 disks
therein. This gives the optimal placement with respect to durability.

The same applies to Ring.get_more_nodes().

Co-Authored-By: Kota Tsuyuzaki <tsuyuzaki.kota@lab.ntt.co.jp>

Change-Id: Ibbd740c51296b7e360845b5309d276d7383a3742

subject: Configurable lxc cache and rootfs path
commit_message:
Configurable lxc cache and rootfs path

The rootfs of the containers use large disk space and is defaulted to
/var/lib/lxc. It's desirable to configure an alternative rootfs directory on a
partition with large enough free space to hold the rootfs.

The rootfs of a container is hard-linked to the lxc cache when created by lxc
templates. Therefore both have to reside on the same partition and the lxc
cache shall be configurable as well as the rootfs directory.

The lxc-ubuntu template is patched by lxc-host role to use the configured lxc
cache folder. This patch should be removed once the updated upstream lxc with
support of configuring the cache path goes mainstream.

To confgiure these parameters, set the following variables in global_overrides
of openstack_user_config.yml:
    - lxc_container_directory, defaults to /var/lib/lxc
    - lxc_container_cache_path, defaults to /var/cache/lxc

subject: Graceful shutdown WSGI server
commit_message:
Graceful shutdown WSGI server

Currently, termination of WSGI application immediately stops service and so
interrupts in-progress request. This could cause problem when do upgrading.

Following related things were done:
1. Removed signal handler for SIGINT to allow instantaneous shutdown.
2. Call launcher.stop() was moved from _child_wait_for_exit_or_signal method
to SIGTERM signal handler and pipe_watcher method because service must not be
stopped for example if SIGHUP comes.
3. Added stop server operation before sending TERM signal to children
processes to close listening socket in master process. Because if socket in
master process is opened, user could successfully connects to API server but
without receiving response.
4. On children side before calling _exit() added call launcher.wait() to allow
gracefully shutdown on SIGTERM.
5. Removed service.wait() from Services.stop() to make it not-blocking call.
6. Removed stop-start operations from Services.restart method because of two
reasons:
  - why stop/start service if we have reset() service's method;
  - to allow graceful shutdown implementation of service.stop() must contain
    closing listening server socket. And there is no possibility to open new
    socket and bind it with current address/port in service.start method if it
    was closed.

DocImpact: graceful termination of process can be done by sending SIGTERM
signal to parent WSGI process. Graceful termination is not instantaneous.
To force instantaneous termination SIGINT signal must be sent.

Change-Id: If25f9565d832d1c36642ec3b1921563ef02890aa
Closes-bug: #1382390

Database changes for conductor horizontal scale

Add database APIs for a conductor to lock/steal/release a bay.
There will be more than one conductors, so it is necessary to
implement a distributed locking APIs to prevent race conditions.

* Lock acquisition: A conductor should acquire a lock when it is
  about to perform an operation on a bay (e.g. create/update/delete
  a bay). The conductor should check the return value of the APIs
  to determine if the lock is successfully acquired. If yes, another
  conductor that attempts to lock the same bay will not succeed.
  Upon completion, the conductor should release the acquired lock to
  allow other conductors to operate the bay later.
* Lock stealing: If conductor A acquires a lock and crashes
  unexpectedly, conductor B can steal the lock acquired by
  conductor A. To do that, conductor B needs to give the id of
  conductor A along with other parameters. The lock stealing will
  succeed if the bay is indeed locked by conductor A at the moment
  of the stealing requests.

Change-Id: I95f28361eea361d878d2c047937c3beef4fb445a
Partial-Implements: blueprint horizontal-scale

subject: Devstack to support an IPv6 infra installation
commit_message:
Devstack to support an IPv6 infra installation

Currently devstack provides the necessary support to have an IPv4 based
OpenStack infrastructure where the services are binded to IPv4 addresses.
However, it does not support an IPv6 infra installation where OpenStack
services are binded to IPv6 addresses.

While testing such a setup, it is observed that some of the parameters
are not configurable/set by devstack. Because of this, the respective
openstack components would use the default values for some parameters
(which generally fall-back to using the IPv4 address of the host).

This patch would help us in configuring the required parameters, to achieve
an IPv6 based OpenStack setup.

Closes-Bug: #1447692
Change-Id: If13e60ee879395e07f26c0094b1b4c0dd481bd51
